name: Eurasian Pygmy Owl
description: It is the smallest owl not only in our region but in all of Europe. Its distinctive features include yellow eyes, a barely noticeable facial disc, and a round head without ear tufts.
spread_note: Northern belt of Eurasia, patchily in Central Europe
image_alt: Eurasian Pygmy Owl, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 10–11.5 cm; tail length 5.5–6.5 cm; wingspan 45 cm; weight 55–80 g
attractions: It lives secretively but likes to perch on treetops, where you might spot it, recognizable by the twitching of its relatively long tail among other signs. It inhabits old mountain forests and is a remnant of the Ice Age in our region—a so-called glacial relict. Its main range lies in the northern taiga, spreading to Central Europe with Quaternary glaciation. As the glacier receded, isolated populations remained in cooler mountain zones, though it is now expanding into foothills and lower altitudes. Pygmy owls live in pairs. During courtship, both partners emit a soft, yet audible whistle. They nest in tree hollows, often taking over woodpecker nests. Both parents feed the chicks.
breeding: We have kept and bred pygmy owls since 1992, with a short break from 2002–2004.
